awd_titl_txt: Viral micro-epidemics and evolutionary dynamics in bacterial biofilms
awd_abstract_narration:
Bacteria build microscopic communities, termed biofilms, and much like human communities, biofilms provide bacteria with stability and increased resilience. Biofilms can be beneficial, for instance in industrial wastewater treatment systems, or as part of a healthy gut microbiota. However, biofilms can also cause damage to various industrial and health systems, even resulting in potentially lethal drug-resistant infections. An important new approach in the control of biofilm populations is the prescriptive use of viral parasites, called phages, to attack harmful bacteria within the biofilms. Though biofilms and phages are ubiquitous in nature, little is known about biofilm-phage interactions. In this project, investigators will develop new techniques to spatio-temporally track the real-time spread of phage infections within biofilm colonies. Using an integrated computational simulation and experimental platform, researchers will investigate mechanisms by which phages infect biofilms, the existence and evolution of infection-resistance within biofilm-dwelling bacteria, and explore the possibility of leveraging the knowledge gained in the control of microbial community composition. In addition, as part of the educational broader impacts of the project, the PI will develop hands-on teaching modules for K-12 students in surrounding rural communities. 

Biofilms are stress-tolerant bacterial communities composed of cells embedded in a secreted matrix of extracellular adhesives. The biofilm mode of growth is commonplace, existing within the microbiomes of living surfaces of plants and animals. Another ubiquitous feature of bacterial biofilms is exposure to bacteriophages. While biofilm-dwelling bacteria presumably encounter phages often, very little is known about bacteria-phage interactions within biofilms on the cellular scales that are crucial for understanding microbial evolution. This gap in understanding is due in part to the absence of appropriate theoretical and experimental techniques for interrogating phage-biofilm interactions. To address this gap, the PI proposes to develop and use techniques from individual-based modeling to simulate biofilm-phage interactions.  Investigators will also develop a new experimental system to mimic biofilm-phage infection.  The system will consist of Escherichia coli and phage T7  co-cultured in a microfluidic platform to enable direct visualization of the phage infection process using high-throughput confocal microscopy. Investigators will leverage their novel, integrated theoretical and experimental platform to study (1) the influence of phage exposure on the evolution of biofilm formation, and (2) the influence of biofilm architecture on the evolution of phage resistance. Anticipated outcomes from this research will lead to an increased understanding of the relatively unquantified bacteria-phage interaction dynamics within biofilms.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Microbes are ubiquitous in the environment, and in many circumstances, they live in densely populated, often surface-bound groups of cells that are held together by a set of secreted glue-like polymers termed the extracellular matrix. This form of group growth, called biofilm formation, is important for the many ways bacteria affect the world around us, including human health. Another common feature of bacterial natural history is exposure to bacteriophages (or phages, for short), which are viruses that specifically target bacterial hosts. Though biofilm formation and phage exposure are both regular parts of bacterial life, and though they likely often occur together, phage infection dynamics within bacterial biofilms has received very little research attention using microscopy approaches to track what is happening on a cell-to-cell basis. The purpose of this grant was to establish both computational and experimental tools to study phage-biofilm interaction at high resolution, and to perform the first studies examining how biofilm structure influences the fundamental ecology, evolution, and mechanics of host-phage interaction.

 

In prior work we showed that for biofilms of the model bacterium Escherichia coli, mature matrix structure can trap phages on the biofilm outer surface and stop them from diffusing into the interior space. As a result, the biofilm population can continue to grow rather than succumbing to phage killing. In work funded here by the NSF, we demonstrated that phages trapped on the biofilm outer surface actually remain active and viable: they can still kill incoming cells that might otherwise attach to the biofilm?s outer surface. This may affect how microbial communities are assembled through time in a variety of environments and circumstances. We also showed that the impeded movement of phages through biofilms makes it much easier than normal for phage-resistant and phage-susceptible bacteria to co-exist. This happens because when the phage-resistant bacteria are common, it becomes harder for phages to contact groups of phage-susceptible cells; when susceptible cells are common, on the other hand, it is common for phages to encounter and kill them, leaving open space for the resistant bacteria to grow. We demonstrated, via extensive computational simulations, that this protection effect for susceptible cells should generalize for a wide variety of conditions and parameters of environmental conditions, bacterial growth, phage life history features, phage resistance mechanisms, and the timing of biofilm exposure to phage threats. In another publication studying phage exposure to multispecies biofilms of E. coli and Vibrio cholerae, we provided further support for the generality of these conclusions. Overall, this work has established a first foundation for understanding phage-bacteria interaction at high resolution in biofilms. The work informs our understanding of fundamental microbial ecology, but also will help to define the conditions under which phage applications for antibacterial therapy might be effective or ineffective depending on the nature of pathogen biofilm growth.

 

NSF funding for this work facilitated the training of 5 undergraduate students, 5 PhD graduate students, and 1 postdoctoral scholar over the length of the award. In the process these funds encouraged the development of several more project lines as offshoots of the main biofilm-phage work that motivated the proposal, including the first studies of the bacterial predator Bdellovibrio bacteriovorus attacking biofilm-dwelling bacteria. The early cohorts of these students are now graduated and moved on to positions in biotechnology and further academic research. Funding from this award also supported visiting lectures to local high school biology classes as well as a summer science academy for middle and his school students in the region to develop and pursue independent research projects in the biological sciences.
